article_title: Millennials want cash, choice to engage in wellness
article_text:
For benefits managers and HR professionals who value planning for the future, cracking the puzzle of how to appeal to millennials can be challenging.

This up-and-coming generation of workers, generally defined as having been born between 1984 and 1996, prizes independence as few other recent generations has. But they will still go to work and, for the most part, work for someone else. Data about their habits, preferences and attitudes toward work and money continues to emerge.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: Dan Cook

og.description: In general, millennials are much more excited about the "quantified self" movement than are older generations.

article_summary:
For benefits managers and HR professionals who value planning for the future, cracking the puzzle of how to appeal to millennials can be challenging.
This up-and-coming generation of workers, generally defined as having been born between 1984 and 1996, prizes independence as few other recent generations has.
Data about their habits, preferences and attitudes toward work and money continues to emerge.
But they will still go to work and, for the most part, work for someone else.
